conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the given p-T and V-T graphs to determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K.
The p-T graph shows pressure (p) on the y-axis and temperature (T) on the x-axis, while the V-T graph shows volume (V) on the y-axis and temperature (T) on the x-axis.
The p-T graph shows a straight line, indicating a linear relationship between pressure and temperature.
The V-T graph shows a straight line, indicating a linear relationship between volume and temperature.
Identify the temperature on the p-T graph. The temperature is marked at 600 K.
Locate the point on the p-T graph corresponding to 600 K. The graph shows a straight line, indicating a constant pressure for this temperature.
Read the pressure value from the p-T graph at 600 K. The point on the graph corresponds to a pressure of 1.5 × 10^5 Pa.
Verify that the temperature and pressure match the conditions given in the problem. The temperature is 600 K, and the pressure is 1.5 × 10^5 Pa.
Conclude that the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.5 × 10^5 Pa.

The problem involves understanding the relationship between temperature, pressure, and volume for an ideal gas. The p-T graph shows how these variables change with temperature, while the V-T graph shows how volume changes with temperature.
The problem provides a p-T graph and a V-T graph. The graph for p-T shows a straight line, indicating constant pressure. The graph for V-T shows a straight line, indicating constant volume.

The problem asks for the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K. The graph for p-T shows a straight line with constant pressure, which means the pressure remains constant at 1.5 × 10^5 Pa for this temperature.
